channel.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - App Travel Section
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

image.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - App Travel Section

channel.copyright: Copyright (c) 2023 Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: Ritz-Carlton's $6,400-a-week luxury superyacht cruise has finally set sail
item.description: Ritz-Carlton's highly-anticipated superyacht cruise has finally made its debut, three and a half years after its maiden voyage was originally scheduled to begin.

item.title: The Italian village with the 'elixir' of healthy life
item.description: It's a place of terraced lemon groves, a paradoxically warm mountain breeze, and a powerful fat-killing gene carried by a few lucky residents.

item.title: Virgin Boeing 747 to launch rocket into space
item.description: At the far southwestern tip of England, dangling into the Atlantic, the remote region of Cornwall rarely feels like the center of the world.

item.title: The hunt for the world's most elusive shipwrecks
item.description: In March 2022, the world let out a collective gasp when the remarkably preserved shipwreck of Ernest Shackleton's HMS Endurance was discovered almost two miles beneath the icy Antarctic seas.

item.title: This man built a plane for his family in his garden
item.description: It wasn't until he moved near to an airfield in the UK over a decade ago that mechanical engineer Ashok Aliseril Thamarakshan began to seriously consider learning to fly a plane.

item.title: Secrets from the world's toughest dining scene
item.description: Hong Kong is widely considered one of the most challenging cities in the world to operate a restaurant -- a roiling cauldron of changing tastes, cleaver-sharp competition and unsavory economics.

item.title: She asked a stranger for directions on vacation. Two weeks later they were engaged
item.description: Rachel Décoste landed in West Africa's Republic of Benin in August 2018, anticipating an important journey of self-discovery, but not predicting the extent to which the trip would change her life.

item.title: The Italian town with a boozy secret
item.description: It's super strong, fennel-flavored, as transparent as water -- and in many households across Sardinia it's still produced illegally.

item.title: Cappadocia: One of Turkey's most spectacular hiking destinations
item.description: A rich palette of shimmering caramel swirls, ochers, creams and pinks unfolds across the landscape like an enormous handwoven carpet. Stands of poplars line paths carved by ancient lava flows from three now extinct volcanoes, crisscrossing valleys studded with conical peribacı.

item.title: This Italian icon looks like you've never seen it before
item.description: For over 500 years, Michelangelo's sculpture of David in Florence has stood unchanged, the marble icon of masculinity, and one of the world's most famous works of art.

item.title: The European capital of cool that keeps getting cooler
item.description: Lisbon is in the midst of a renaissance. The latest European capital of cool's affordable rents, great nightlife and gorgeous streets -- which wind high into the hills from the River Tagus -- have seen younger travelers arrive in their droves in recent years, enjoying extended stays thanks to dedicated "digital nomad" visas.

item.title: Best Chinese food: 32 dishes every traveler should try
item.description: With one of the world's most diverse food scenes, China makes it nearly impossible to put together one single list that truly encompasses the "best" Chinese dishes.

item.title: Are you brave enough to sleep in the 'Ghostbusters' firehouse this Halloween?
item.description: There's something strange going on in this Oregon neighborhood.

item.title: Time Out picks the 'world's coolest' neighborhood for 2022
item.description: The top 10 includes the nightlife haven of Cais do Sodré in Lisbon and New York City's beloved Ridgewood, but which neighborhood took the top spot in Time Out's round-up?

item.title: Chiles are so important to this state, they made a law about them
item.description: For New Mexicans, chile isn't just a food, it's a way of life. Chiles are so important, New Mexico is only state to have an "official" question, "Red or green?"

item.title: All the restaurants Stanley Tucci visited in season two of 'Searching for Italy'
item.description: After watching the wanderlust-inducing "Stanley Tucci: Searching for Italy," you'll undoubtedly be hungry.

item.title: Animal sacrifices and pagan worship on the edge of Europe
item.description: An untouched and remote region in northeastern Georgia, Tusheti is a wild trekking paradise of mountains and ancient villages where pagan rites are still observed alongside Christian beliefs.

item.title: Bamboo vipers and many-banded kraits: Experiencing Hong Kong's snake safari
item.description: A fraction of a second after William Sargent's torch light catches the unmistakable glint of snake skin he roars into action, sliding on a protective glove and launching himself into the dense green jungle of northern Hong Kong.

item.title: Yayoi Kusama's yellow pumpkin sculpture is back on Naoshima Island, Japan
item.description: Japanese artist Yayoi Kusama's famous yellow pumpkin sculpture was reinstalled on October 4th on Naoshima island after it was swept into the sea and badly damaged during a typhoon last summer.

item.title: Giant roadside Cheeto attracts a crowd
item.description: A giant Cheeto with massive fingers coated in orange dust becomes a roadside attraction. CNN's Jeanne Moos eats her way through the story.

item.title: Hong Kong offers 500,000 free air tickets to tempt tourists back
item.description: Hong Kong attracted around 56 million visitors a year before the pandemic, and now the popular destination is taking significant steps to win tourists back after over two years of some of the world's toughest travel restrictions.

item.title: Asia Pacific set to lose title as the world's largest travel region
item.description: Asia Pacific is home to some of the world's most beloved travel destinations, from the natural beauty of Bali to the urban buzz of Singapore. These dreamy vacation hotspots -- teamed with the region's business power -- secured Asia Pacific the title of world's largest travel region for much of the past decade.

item.title: The world's best bars for 2022 have been revealed
item.description: Move over London. Step aside New York. There's a new cosmopolitan cocktail capital: Barcelona is home to Paradiso, the newly crowned world's best bar.

item.title: The rise of sleep tourism
item.description: Going on a vacation might seem like a rather unconventional way to try to improve your sleep habits.

item.title: The secrets of Turkey's historic capital of cool
item.description: At first glance Izmir looks very much like any other modern Turkish metropolis, densely populated with unimposing architecture.

item.title: FAA to announce rule allowing more rest for flight attendants
item.description: Federal aviation officials plan to announce Tuesday that flight attendants will soon get more mandated rest time between flights, two sources familiar with the announcement tell CNN.

item.title: The 'tombstone village' built by Korean refugees on a Japanese cemetery
item.description: At first glance, Ami-dong seems like an ordinary village within the South Korean city of Busan, with colorful houses and narrow alleys set against looming mountains.

item.title: 20 best German foods
item.description: German food is rich, hearty and diverse. It's comfort eating with high-quality, often locally sourced ingredients.

item.title: Hong Kong is opening up to tourism -- but is it too late?
item.description: The city hopes the move will revive its status as an international business and travel hub, but the locals said the change may be too late.

item.title: Amid global crises, superyachts are selling more than ever. Here's why
item.description: The specter of global conflict lurks on the horizon. Energy prices are putting the squeeze on millions. Covid lingers. But at the yachting world's most glamorous event, it's business as usual.
